poem:
**Chopped Narrative**  

Fragments scatter –  
the red of winter finds its shape,  
each piece, a whisper  
of the whole unraveling—  

jealousy,  
tangled in the threads  
of time and memory,  
a mosaic built  
on broken edges,  
whispered around  
corners of a dream,  
each pause,  
a shadow turning.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Scarlet Winter review – chopped-up narrative method decorates corpse-disposal thriller Mulholland Drive and Memento are celebrated examples of how narrative fragmentation can dovetail well with the philosophical heart and aims of film noir. While this low-budget thriller doesn’t have the finesse of either of those films, it does at least aim high in its sundered viewpoint on the jealousy-filled menage à trois at its centre. Debut director Munjal Yagnik plays it entirely non-linear to begin". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
